item.content:encoded: Baby Bump As so-called "killer whales" have made news over the past few years for violent boat attacks in European waters, marine biologists have noticed a far sweeter behavior in Iceland's frigid waves: the adoption of a baby whale from an entirely different species. In interviews with Scientific American, scientists described their shock at observing, over a period of years, a pilot whale calf that traveled with an Icelandic pod of orcas. item.title: Something Wild Happens When You Try to Take a Video of a Car's Sensors
item.content:encoded: Public service announcement: don't point your phone camera directly at a lidar sensor. On Reddit, a user named Jeguetelli recently shared a video demonstrating why.  As the camera zooms in on the sensor affixed to the top of a Volvo EX90, a whole galaxy of colorful dots are burned into the image, forming over the exact spot that the flashing light inside the lidar device can be seen. What you're witnessing isn't lens flare or a digital glitch — it's real, physical damage to the lens. And it's permanent. "Lidar lasers burn your camera," the user warned.  Lidar is short […]

item.title: Startup Claims Its "Superwood" Is Stronger Than Steel
item.content:encoded: TK A new startup is making the bold claim that it can mass-produce "Superwood," which it says is stronger and lighter than steel, with 90 percent lower carbon emissions compared to steel. If that sounds wild, it's because it is. item.title: AI Chatbots Are Becoming Even Worse At Summarizing Data
item.content:encoded: Ask the CEO of any AI startup, and you'll probably get an earful about the tech's potential to "transform work," or "revolutionize the way we access knowledge." Really, there's no shortage of promises that AI is only getting smarter — which we're told will speed up the rate of scientific breakthroughs, streamline medical testing, and breed a new kind of scholarship. But according to a new study published in the Royal Society, as many as 73 percent of seemingly reliable factual answers from AI chatbots could actually be inaccurate. item.title: World Leaders Shown AI Baby Versions of Themselves at European Summit
item.content:encoded: Baby Erdoğan's Mustache It's called diplomacy, guys. This year's European Political Community, an annual forum for European leaders founded in 2022 following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, kicked off on Friday in Tirana, Albania. There were flashing lights and dance performances, and a few different video sequences. item.content:encoded: A team of researchers at the University of California, Davis, made small tweaks to the DNA structure of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) to see if it could be turned into an effective brain-healing treatment for patients that suffer from conditions like schizophrenia — without risking a potentially disastrous acid trip. item.title: What Are Alien Dyson Spheres, Why Are They So Janky, and Why Are They Doomed to Go Undetected?
item.content:encoded: In the 1960s, physicist Freeman Dyson proposed that advanced alien civilizations could be building out enormous megastructures around a star to harness much of its energy. These shells, dubbed Dyson spheres, could be giving off distinct technosignatures, astronomers have suggested, allowing us to glimpse them from many light-years away. Yet, despite our best efforts, we have yet to make first contact, let alone with a megastructure siphoning off the energy released by a star. item.title: Study: Living Near a Golf Course Could Lead to a Terrible Chronic Illness
item.content:encoded: A controversial new study has found that those who live in close proximity to a golf course may face up to three times the odds of developing Parkinson's disease, a progressive neurological disorder that causes tremors and difficulty with balance. According to a new population-based case-control study published in the journal JAMA Network Open, environmental risks, including pesticide exposure and groundwater contamination, could be contributing to the risk of developing Parkinson's. In the United States, golf courses are treated with extremely high levels of pesticides, which could be hazardous to human health. The team examined medical records of over 5,000 […]

item.title: General Motors Unveils Their "Groundbreaking" New EV Battery
item.content:encoded: General Motors is a something of a silent warrior among electric vehicle giants. Though they weren't a hit with car buyers, the company's early efforts at EV development back in the 1990s paved the way for the Teslas and Rivians of today. As far back as 1990, GM engineers were pioneering many of the standard features found on electric vehicles two and a half decades later, like keyless ignition, tire-pressure sensors, heat-pump HVAC, and electric-defrosting windows. item.title: Amazon’s Delivery Drones Are Crashing, and We Finally Know Why
item.content:encoded: Amazon, the multi-trillion dollar e-commerce monolith, seemingly cheaped out on keeping a key feature installed on its delivery six-propeller drones. The crashes, which destroyed both aircraft, happened within minutes of each other.  And now, Bloomberg reports, we know why. item.title: AI Is Helping Job Seekers Lie, Flood the Market, and Steal Jobs
item.content:encoded: The advent of generative AI has fundamentally altered the job application process. Both recruiters and applicants are making ample use of the tech, making an already soul-sucking and tedious process even worse. According to a recent campaign by insurer Hiscox, [lol] more than half of recent job applicants said they had used AI tools to write their resumes. item.title: In a World First, CRISPR Drug Tailored for One Baby Shows Life-Saving Promise
item.content:encoded: Scientists used CRISPR tech to create a custom-made drug targeted at helping a newborn baby fight a rare genetic disorder. item.title: NASA’s James Webb Telescope Just Found Frozen Water Around Another Star
item.content:encoded: Water ice is a crucial building block of planetary systems. We've found plenty of it in our own Solar System, in places like Europa, Mars, and wayward comets, but we've never made a definitive detection of frozen water around other stars. Plenty of water vapor, yes, but no ice. But that just changed. Using NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, a team of astronomers have confirmed the presence of water ice in a debris disk encircling a young, Sun-like star just 155 light years away.
